channel.title: aws on Barefoot Rob
channel.description: Recent content in aws on Barefoot Rob

item.title: late work uploading files to AWS support
item.description: Login at https://admin.ab.redacted.example.com See 502 Bad Gateway In the request, change https to http See 502 Bad Gateway bypass ELB by placing this in local /etc/hosts file 13.23.21.14 admin.ab.redacted.example.com reload the request with http OR https the request works Those are redacted instructions that showed AWS support that something seemed amiss with the elastic load balancer. M helped me activate tcpdump and we captured output while recreating the error in different capacities.

item.title: Turns out I am *not* eligible for AWS free tier
item.description: 20:26 Thursday 18 April 2019 JST It turns out I am not eligible for AWS free tier.. Thank goodness for their billing alarms. It went off at $3 and I was like whhaaa?? It turns out free tier is only for new customers less than a year old. I have had my account for ages.. Why would their interface say free tier next to anything while I am logged in?

item.title: urbit ~rabsef-linmyn
item.description: 14:10 Friday 12 April 2019 JST I got my urbit planet running the other day on my local machine. After some playing around I determined that I should be able to run it on AWS on a t2.micro which fits within their free tier.

item.title: trying to get SSL working on cloudfront (not solved)
item.description: 15:24 Friday 02 March 2018 JST We have an image server behind cloudfront. Cloudfront can serve everything via https when using its subdomain. But using our own domain with https isn’t as easy as I would like. Running Lets Encrypt on the server, I get an error like the https request was not allowed. So I created a certificate with AWS Certificate Manager and told Cloudfront to use it, but I do not see how to tell the server to use it.

item.title: Chillin in Tullys
item.description: 15:55 Monday 20 November 2017 JST I’m getting back into Ansible groove on AWS. Thanks to Ansible for making it relatively easy to set up AWS boxes.

item.title: playing with AWS for sbs.net
item.description: 12:27 Wednesday 15 November 2017 JST Not actually sbs.net, but yes actually AWS. Using Ansible again, thanks to Travis having suggested it to me. Right now as I write this entry, AWS my wifi in this cafe is being slow to realize that my VPC is already created. Not sure why, as it was fast a moment ago. Yep it just timed out. The error was: ssl.SSLError: The read operation timed out Previously, I was getting

item.title: Elastic Load Balancer on Amazon Web Services
item.description:
13:57 Saturday 06 February 2016 JST Sweet! Thanks to https://acloud.guru/course/aws-certified-solutions-architect-associate/learn/ec2/load-balancers-health-checks I have created a proof of concept set of web servers connected by a load balancer which automatically scales depending on usage requirements.
The terminated instances were automagically replaced with the running instances. :-)

item.title: missed the point
item.description: 16:33 Wednesday 13 January 2016 JST Now, I’m not 100% sure this is a bug, but I reported to AWS a few days ago: S3 bug: cannot create two lifecycle rules that apply to whole S3 bucket That’s just the title; I spelled it out a bit in the body of the message. But today I got back a steaming pile of useless reply: Hello Rob, This is ______ from the AWS Billing Department.

item.title: juggling data
item.description: ##09:33 Thursday 12 February 2015 JST## Yesterday I worked several hours trying to get my AWS instance to talk to an RDS instance on a VPC. I set “Publically accessable” to true, set the Security group to (wide open/allow the AWS instance security group), but I still couldn’t connect. My great idea now is to create an AMI based on the AWS instance, then spin up a new instance of the AMI in the same VPC as the RDS.

item.title: Moving hakyll.robnugen.com to dreamhost
item.description: ##13:36 Wednesday 10 December 2014 JST## I eventually want to have a cloud server on which I have root access, but right now, especially for this site, I don’t need it. On Dreamhost, I killed the DNS entry pointing hakyll.robnugen.com to my EC2 instance, then asked Dreamhost to host hakyll.robnugen.com, but the DNS doesn’t seem to have updated yet. HI! I had a custom DNS record pointing hakyll.robnugen.com to an IP on Amazon AWS server.

item.title: Tutorial- running Hakyll for free on AWS
item.description: ##20:20 Thursday 30 October 2014 JST## These notes should work for *nix, including OS X, which I’m using. Windows users may have to adapt when it comes to local stuff. Easy as get server with root access set up Nginx on server set up Hakyll locally ##1. sign up for AWS micro (free tier available)## I will probably go with all their defaults: ####Step 1:#### For this, I’m using Amazon Linux AMI 2014.

item.title: Logged in to AWS (I know you were worried)
item.description: Was able to login to AWS this morning. Turns out I don’t have a MFA token. Bah. Note to future self: my login URL is https://thunderrabbit.signin.aws.amazon.com/console

item.title: Running Hakyll on AWS
item.description: Running Hakyll on Dreamhost AWS UPDATE: Run Hakyll for free on AWS is a better tutorial than the mess below. I gave up trying to install Hakyll on Dreamhost when I realized I probably wouldn’t be able to install Haskell at all. I have a ticket in to DH now, but I bet they’ll say “sorry, not on shared hosting; why don’t you try our VPS?” The following is based on notes I took from https://marcanuy.

item.title: AWS makin' me crazy
item.description: Why can’t I log in to AWS? My password is stored in my password manager; my MFA token is working fine. Moe Joe this is not something I want to fight each time I need to make a change on website. Bah.
